title.narrative: Sustainable Inclusive Business (SIB-K)

description.narrative: Driving private sector (together with civil society, Non-Governmental Organisations (NGOs) and Governments) towards being sustainable and inclusive. This is achieved by empowering and supporting enterprises to embrace sustainability in their business models, reduce their carbon footprint and negative impact on the planet, and increase their positive impact on people while generating profit.
Private sector, government, civil society and academia

a. Increase awareness, knowledge and social dialogue on the importance and opportunities of Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR), sustainability and inclusiveness among Small & Medium Enterprises (SMEs) and corporate. b. Expand and strengthen the application of sustainable inclusive business principles, strategies and practices within businesses and organisations (small, medium and large).

title.narrative: Number of policy interventions/input submitted to/through KEPSA sector boards.

comment.narrative: Team is actively involved in the Environment; Education; Gender & Youth and Agriculture sector boards. SIB-K contributed to the Sustainable Waste Management Policy in 2019 and the ongoing Extended Producer Responsibility regulations 2020. The SIB-K team participated and contributed in the development of the No Single Use Plastic Ban action plan on protected areas together with the KEPSA Environmental Sector Board. SIB-K’s participation on the Environmental Sector Board led to the development of the Circular Economy sub-sector board under the Environmental sector board. The National Solid Waste Management bill and policy was approved by cabinet.

title.narrative: # of organisations adopting SIB practices or changing their operations to become more sustainable and inclusive

comment.narrative: The EPR initiative garnered 33 businesses who committed to be part of the producer responsibility organisation, which will lead to increased collection and recycling of plastic packaging material. In order to guide this process SIB-K in collaboration with KAM developed a PRO business model. 13 business supported in the COAST Project

title.narrative: # of consultancy activities carried out.

comment.narrative: SIB-K a knowledge centre at KEPSA implemented an assignment in collaboration with KAM funded by the Netherlands Enterprise Agency to develop a business model for an Producer Responsibility Organisation, the COAST project as well as the knowledge sharing session for women in the flower sector. Waste Management Study (Zimbabwe, Zambia, Malawi), Kenya E-Waste Study, Review of SUP Regulations in East Africa, WWF OPOB Conference, IUCN Documented Best Practices.

comment.narrative: SIB-K team undertook an eight-week online course on Introduction to Circular Economy offered on the edX platform. Others underwent a training on project management. During a monthly meeting staff were trained in financial investment and health.

comment.narrative: The first work shop was on e-waste where 4 business participated: Close the Gap, Kenya; WEEE Centre; Sinomet Kenya Ltd and Recykla International. 2 other workshops were conducted on single-use plastic and supply chain management. A total of 60 participants joined the discussions. 80% of the participants were satisfied with the webinar and acknowledged that the webinar increases awareness on policy hence lead to change in operations through a poll conducted.

title.narrative: Promoting SIB principles through mass media channels such as TV and newspapers

description.narrative: # of TV/ Radio appearances including interviews.

comment.narrative: 23 TV and Radio interviews were conducted. The Kenya Tourism Federation joined the discussion therefore bringing into the discourse the role of the hotel industry in ensuring the environment is conserved. The aim here was to raise awareness on the single use plastic ban in restricted areas e.g. National Parks, Forests, Beaches and National Reserves. Other interviews focused on EPR Regulations 2020, Waste Management Policy as well as the adoption of sustainable business practises. SIB-K was hosted at Spice FM and BBC to deliberate in circular economy matters.

title.narrative: Promoting SIB principles through mass media channels such as TV and newspapers.

description.narrative: # of published newspaper and online articles on sustainability and inclusiveness

comment.narrative: SIB-K published 143 articles (articles published in the newspaper and online platforms). The articles focused on the need to reduce the disposal of plastic in the environment. Other articles sought to raise awareness on the single-use plastics ban that took effect on the 5th of June 2020. This initiated a conversation on the need to find alternatives based on the list of items to be restricted in protected areas. This includes parks, national parks, national reserves, beaches and forests. The need to adopt resilient business practices was raised. Other conversations aimed to increase awareness on separation of waste at source and the transition to a circular economy.

title.narrative: Number of businesses that contribute and transform through the meetings and fora.

comment.narrative: The first work shop was on e-waste where 4 business participated: Close the Gap, Kenya; WEEE Centre; Sinomet Kenya Ltd and Recykla International. 2 other workshops were conducted on single-use plastic and supply chain management. A total of 60 participants joined the discussions. 80% of the participants were satisfied with the webinar and acknowledged that the webinar increase awareness on policy hence lead to change in operations through a poll conducted. 71 businesses participated in the 1st webinar of a webinar series on PPPs in the sector organized in collaboration with 2030WRG.

title.narrative: # of companies, academia, civil society and government agencies participating in the engagement.

comment.narrative: The 2020 SIB-K annual conference was hosted on the 18th of September 2020, with a total of 230 registrations. Discussions were geared towards the shift to a circular economy as well as opportunities and risks presented to the private sector. The virtual event was attended by; Amb. Maarten Brouwer, Amb. Simon Mordue and Amb. Erik Lundberg and Dr. Ayub Macharia, Ministry of Environment and Forestry. Ms. Carole Karuga, our circular economy champion, led the call to the private sector to support the shift from a linear to a circular economy.

title.narrative: # of speaking and moderating sessions.

comment.narrative: SIB-K participated in several workshop on e-waste, waste to value accelerator program organized by the Best Sellers Foundation, the eco-warrior awards, KOEE Litter Less Online Forum, a webinar on sustainable procurement with SSP, a business forum organized by the Strathmore Business School on waste management, setup of the COAST Project, Review of Dutch policy on Responsible Business Responsibility, webinar on single use plastic, webinar on the EPR 2020 Regulations, SNV’s Research webinar on the impact of COVID-19 on food systems, and a webinar on Sustainability in the Wake of Covid-19: Perspectives from Business, Higher Education, Utility Management, Waste Management organized in collaboration with the Committee on Fiscal Studies (CFS) and the Global Challenge Research Fund (GDRF) one health initiative.

title.narrative: # of social media impressions

comment.narrative: The project has surpassed the target on impressions on Twitter, LinkedIn, Facebook. The improvement can be attributed to the project’s communication strategy to use online platforms as the major communication channels during the COVID-19 pandemic. The target has been revised upwards to 1,500,000 impressions.

title.narrative: # of successful partnerships made between businesses/organisations.

comment.narrative: 4 organisations were able to develop partnerships through the Partner Up Platform created on the web portal. The platform created an opportunity for businesses with an ask/need to partner with businesses or institutions that have the capacity to purchase a product or support an initiative during the COVID period. Sunworld Safaris, UCESCO, KOEE and SSP were able to build partnerships.
